newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL noon rubber holds steady amid INRO watch.
newsitem.headline: KL noon rubber holds steady amid INRO watch.

text.p: Malaysian rubber prices were steady at midday on technical adjustment and news of SMR20 sales to Germany and China, traders said.

The International Natural Rubber Organisation was, meanwhile, studying the possibility of entering the market to support prices after its five-day indicator price slipped to a level where it could buy rubber from the market.
"The market's still a bit sluggish but there was some sales reported today," said a government trade source.
Some 1,000 tonnes of August SMR20 was reported sold to China at 232 cents a kg while a similar load was reported traded to Germany at 230 cents a kg, said the government source.

At midday, the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board quoted the RSS1 buyer for August at 227 cents a kg and SMR 20 buyer for August at 232 cents. Both grades were unchanged from Thursday's closing prices.
The INRO's five-day indicator was at 182.48 cents a kg on July 10, compared to the 183.56 cents on July 9.
At midday, trading houses quoted the SMR CV at 299 cents, SMR L at 280, SMR5 at 244, SMR10 at 235 and latex at 198 cents.
Malaysia-based shipping brokers quoted freight rates for rubber from Malaysia to Rotterdam at $700 per 20-ft container, and $1,400 per 40-ft container.
